headline.main: SUMMER LETTERS.; Letter-Links between New-York and Virginia. NUMBER TWELVE. Travel from the Hot Springs -- Scenery -- White Sulphur Springs.

byline.original: Correspondence of the New--York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: More Coroners' Inquests--Forty Additional Deaths Recorded Yesterday-Unfounded Rumors of Yellow Fever at Quarantine. The extensive list of deaths from the excessive heat of Saturday and Sunday, which we published yesterday, did not comprise nearly all the fatal cases that occurred on those days.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bulletin says the record for the week ending yesterday morning at 6 o'clock, is terrible. We have no words whereby we can characterise the fearfulness of the scourge. The plain statement,--the mute but awful figures,--tell the tale, concisely, but appallingly.

headline.main: FOUR DAYS LATER FROM EUROPE.; ARRIVAL OF THE HUMBOLDT. Doubtful Aspect of the Turkish Question. Progress and Character of the Chinese Rebellion. ACTION OF THE AMERICAN MINISTER.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U. S. mail steamer Humboldt, Capt. LINES, arrived last evening from Havre vid Southampton, bringing intelligence and files four days later than had been before received. The Humboldt brings 186 passengers and 630 tons of merchandise. Amongst the names of the passengers we notice S. B. GOODRICH, Esq., late U. S. Consul at Paris; Hon. CALEB LYON, of Lyons dale, member of Congress from New-York, and Hon. CHARLES A MANN, of Utica.

docs.lead_paragraph: FILTHY STREETS.-The Grand Jury of NewOrleans have made a presentment with regard to the present state of the city, in which they say: " Without discussing the question whether this epidemic is of foreign or local origin, we have no hesitation in saying that the disease, if not genrated, has been greatly augmented by the filthy condition of the city.

docs.lead_paragraph: We have no epidemic here to set us into a panic. Death does his work quietly, without frightening his victims before their time, or alarming survivors. The number of deaths reported to the City Inspector, for the week ending at 2 o'clock of Saturday, was 585, which is 14 more than the week preceding, and 18 more than the average of the corresponding week last year.
